TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE ( GPE ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant is a physiotherapist who completed his professional training in GPE and received his diploma in DATE . DATE he worked as a physiotherapist in GPE during which time he was employed by an association working in that field .

CARDINAL . On DATE the PERSON Governor ( PERSON ) recognised his diploma with suspensive effect until he accomplished CARDINAL additional exams . On DATE the Regional Governor completed the decree of recognition upon the applicant ’s submission of the required certificates .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a request with the ORG Governor for the authorisation to work as a self - employed physiotherapist . He further submitted an employment certificate dated DATE , which had been issued by the association he had worked for .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Regional Governor refused to grant the applicant ’s request . It found that the applicant did not comply with the requirements set out in section QUANTITY of the Act on ORG ( Bundesgesetz über die GPE medizinisch - technischen CARDINAL , ORG ) . According to this provision the right to work as a self - employed physiotherapist may only be granted after DATE of authorised professional practice within DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Ministerium für Gesundheit und Konsumentenschutz ) partly granted the applicant ’s appeal . It found that the Regional Governor should have based its decision on section QUANTITY of LAW ( Krankenpflegegesetz ) according to which the right to work as a self - employed physiotherapist may already be granted after DATE of authorised professional practice within DATE . It held that , as regards the content , ORG had decided correctly , however , it had based its decision on the wrong legal provision .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a complaint with ORG . He requested an oral hearing and asked the court to seek a preliminary ruling from ORG under Article CARDINAL of LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed another request with the Regional Governor in order to be granted the right to work as a self - employed physiotherapist .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Regional Governor also rejected this request . He held that the applicant was authorised to work as physiotherapist in GPE since DATE following recognition of his foreign diploma . His employment at the association had been before that time and could not be considered as “ authorised ” professional practice within the meaning of section QUANTITY of LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the applicant ’s appeal on formal grounds , applying the principle of res iudicata .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a complaint with ORG , requested an oral hearing and asked the court to seek a preliminary ruling from ORG under LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to deal with the applicant ’s complaint for lack of prospects of success . It found that his case did not raise serious questions of constitutional law or of the application of Community law and that the matter was not excluded from the competence of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a complaint with ORG against the ORG ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE , requesting , inter alia , an oral hearing . He further asked the court to seek a preliminary ruling from ORG under LAW on the question whether the refusal to exercise his profession as a self - employed physiotherapist in GPE was in accordance with Community law .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , in the course of official liability proceedings instituted by the applicant , also requested ORG to decide upon the lawfulness of the decision by ORG of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , in a joint decision , dismissed the applicant ’s complaints of DATE and DATE and the request by ORG without holding an oral hearing , relying on section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW . It confirmed the decisions by ORG as being lawful . It further held that there was no issue that would require a preliminary ruling by ORG , since the applicant ’s requests did not concern the interpretation of a specific provision of Community law but rather challenged the implementation of national law exercised by NORP authorities . The decision was served on the applicant ’s counsel on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , dismissed the applicant ’s claim relating to official liability proceedings . It found that there was no legal basis in national or Community law , which could support the applicant ’s claim .

Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( Verwaltungsgerichtshof - gesetz ) provides that ORG is to hold a hearing after its preliminary investigation of the case where a complainant has requested a hearing within the time - limit . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) provides however :
" Notwithstanding a party ’s application , ORG may decide not to hold a hearing when ( ... )

CARDINAL . It is apparent to the ORG from the written pleadings of the parties to the proceedings before ORG and from the files relating to the prior proceedings that an oral hearing is not likely to contribute to clarifying the case , and if this is not against LAW . "
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW reads as follows :

" ORG may ... decline to accept a case for adjudication if it does not have sufficient prospects of success or if it can not be expected that the judgment will clarify an issue of constitutional law . The ORG may not decline to accept for adjudication a case excluded from the jurisdiction of ORG by Article CARDINAL . "
